original_text: We address the problem of constructing high-accuracy, faithful analytic waveforms describing the gravitational wave signal emitted by inspiralling and coalescing binary black holes. We work within the Effective-One-Body (<font color = red>EOB</font>) framework and propose a methodology for improving the current (<font color = red>waveform</font>)implementations of this framework based on understanding, element by element, the physics behind each feature of the waveform, and on systematically comparing various <font color = red>EOB-based</font> waveforms with ``exact'' waveforms obtained by numerical relativity approaches. The present paper focuses on <font color = red>small-mass-ratio</font> <font color = red>non-spinning</font> binary systems, which can be conveniently studied by <font color = red>Regge-Wheeler-Zerilli-type</font> methods. Our results include: (i) a resummed, <font color = red>3PN-accurate</font> description of the <font color = red>inspiral</font> waveform, (<font color = red>ii</font>) a better description of radiation reaction during the <font color = red>plunge</font>, (iii) a refined <font color = red>analytic</font> expression for the plunge waveform, (iv) an improved treatment of the matching between the plunge and ring-down waveforms. <font color = red>This</font> improved implementation of the <font color = red>EOB</font> approach allows us to construct <font color = red>complete</font> analytic waveforms which exhibit a remarkable agreement with the ``exact'' ones in modulus, frequency and phase. In particular, the analytic and numerical waveforms stay in phase, during the <font color = red>whole</font> process, within $\<font color = red>pm</font> 1.1 %$ of a cycle. We expect that the extension of our methodology to the <font color = red>comparable-mass</font> case will be <font color = red>able</font> to generate comparably accurate analytic waveforms of direct use for the ground-based network of <font color = red>interferometric</font> detectors of gravitational waves.

original_text: We propose a pairing-based method for cooling an atomic <font color = red>Fermi</font> gas. A three component (labels 1, 2, 3) mixture of <font color = red>Fermions</font> is considered where the components 1 and 2 interact and, for instance, form pairs <font color = red>whereas</font> the component 3 is in the normal state. For cooling, the components 2 and 3 are coupled by an electromagnetic field. Since the quasiparticle distributions in the paired and in the normal states are different, the coupling leads to <font color = red>cooling</font> of the normal state even when <font color = red>initially</font> $T_{<font color = red>paired</font>}\geq T_{normal}$ (notation $<font color = red>T_S</font>\geq T_N$). The cooling efficiency is given by the pairing energy and by the <font color = red>linewidth</font> of the coupling field. No superfluidity is required: any type of pairing, or other phenomenon that produces a suitable spectral density, is sufficient. In principle, the paired state could be cooled as <font color = red>well</font> but this requires $<font color = red>T_N</font><<font color = red>T_S</font>$. The method has a conceptual analogy to cooling based on <font color = red>superconductor</font> -- normal metal (<font color = red>SN</font>) tunneling junctions. Main differences arise from the <font color = red>exact</font> momentum <font color = red>conservation</font> in the case of the <font color = red>field-matter</font> coupling vs. non-conservation of momentum in the solid state tunneling process. Moreover, the role of processes that relax the energy conservation requirement in the <font color = red>tunneling</font>, e.g. thermal <font color = red>fluctuations</font> of an external reservoir, is now played by the linewidth of the field. The proposed method should be experimentally feasible due to its close connection to RF-spectroscopy of ultracold <font color = red>gases</font> which is already in use.

original_text: <font color = red>Energetic</font> feedback processes during the formation of galaxy clusters may have heated and ionized a large fraction of the intergalactic gas in proto-cluster regions. When such a highly ionized <font color = red>hot</font> ``super-bubble'' falls along the sightline to a background quasar, it would be seen as a large void, with little or no absorption, in the <font color = red>Lyman</font> alpha forest. <font color = red>We</font> examine the spectra of <font color = red>137</font> <font color = red>quasars</font> in the Sloan Digital Sky <font color = red>Survey</font>, to search for such voids, and find no clear evidence of their existence. The size distribution of voids in the range <font color = red>5-70</font> <font color = red>Angstrom</font> (<font color = red>corresponding</font> to <font color = red>physical</font> sizes of approximately <font color = red>3-35</font> comoving <font color = red>Mpc</font>/h) is consistent with the standard model for the Lyman alpha forest without additional hot bubbles. We adapt a physical model for <font color = red>HII</font> bubble growth during cosmological reionization (<font color = red>Furlanetto</font>, Zaldarriaga and <font color = red>Hernquist</font> 2004), to describe the expected size-distribution of hot super-bubbles at redshift around z = 3. This model incorporates the conjoining of bubbles around individual neighboring galaxies. Using the <font color = red>non-detection</font> of voids, we find that models in which the volume filling factor of hot bubbles exceeds approximately 20 percent at z=3 can be ruled out, primarily because they overproduce the number of <font color = red>large</font> (<font color = red>40-50</font> <font color = red>Angstrom</font>) voids. We conclude that any <font color = red>pre-heating</font> mechanism that explains galaxy cluster observations must avoid heating the <font color = red>low-density</font> gas in the <font color = red>proto-cluster</font> regions, either by operating <font color = red>relatively</font> <font color = red>recently</font> (z<3) or by depositing entropy in the high-density regions.

original_text: Using a <font color = red>semi-analytical</font> model for galaxy formation, combined with a <font color = red>large</font> <font color = red>N-body</font> simulation, we investigate the origin of the dichotomy among <font color = red>early-type</font> galaxies. We find that boxy galaxies originate from mergers with a progenitor mass ratio $n < 2$ and with a combined cold gas <font color = red>mass</font> fraction $<font color = red>F_</font>{\<font color = red>rm</font> <font color = red>cold</font>} < 0.1$. Our model accurately reproduces the observed fraction of <font color = red>boxy</font> systems as a function of luminosity and halo mass, for both central galaxies and satellites. After correcting for the stellar mass dependence, the properties of the <font color = red>last</font> major merger of early-type galaxies are independent of their halo mass. This provides theoretical support for the conjecture of <font color = red>Pasquali</font> <font color = red>et</font> al (<font color = red>2007</font>) that the stellar mass of an early-type galaxy is the main parameter that governs its <font color = red>isophotal</font> shape. <font color = red>We</font> argue that the observed dichotomy of early-type galaxies has a natural explanation within hierarchical structure formation, and does not require <font color = red>AGN</font> feedback. Rather, we argue that it owes to the fact that more massive <font color = red>systems</font> (i) have more massive progenitors, (ii) <font color = red>assemble</font> later, and (<font color = red>iii</font>) have a larger fraction of early-type progenitors. Each of these three trends causes the <font color = red>cold</font> gas mass fraction of the progenitors of more massive early-types to be lower, so that their last major merger was dryer. Finally, our model predicts that (i) <font color = red>less</font> than 10 percent of all early-type galaxies form in major mergers that involve two early-type progenitors, (ii) more than <font color = red>95</font> percent of all boxy early-type galaxies with $M_* < 2 \times 10^{<font color = red>10</font>} h^{-1} \<font color = red>Msun</font>$ are <font color = red>satellite</font> galaxies, and (iii) about 70 percent of all low mass early-types do not form a supermassive black hole binary at their last major merger. The <font color = red>latter</font> may help to explain why low mass early-types have central cusps, while their massive counterparts have cores.

original_text: Numerical simulations suggest that <font color = red>active</font> galactic nuclei (AGNs) <font color = red>play</font> an important role in the formation of early-type galaxies by expelling gas and dust in powerful galactic winds and quenching star formation. However, the existence of AGN feedback capable of halting galaxy-wide star formation has <font color = red>yet</font> to be observationally confirmed. To investigate this question, we have obtained spectra of 14 post-starburst galaxies at z~0.6 to search for evidence of galactic winds. <font color = red>In</font> 10/<font color = red>14</font> galaxies we detect <font color = red>Mg</font> <font color = red>II</font> <font color = red>2796</font>,2803 <font color = red>absorption</font> <font color = red>lines</font> which are <font color = red>blueshifted</font> by 490 - <font color = red>2020</font> km/s with respect to the stars. The median blueshift is <font color = red>1140</font> km/s. We hypothesize that the outflowing gas represents a fossil galactic wind launched near the peak of the galaxy's activity, a few <font color = red>100</font> Myr <font color = red>ago</font>. The velocities we measure are intermediate between those of luminous starbursts and broad absorption line quasars, which suggests that feedback from an AGN may have <font color = red>played</font> a role in expelling cool gas and shutting down star formation.

original_text: A generalized geometric method is developed for constructing exact solutions of gravitational field equations in Einstein theory and generalizations. First, we apply the formalism of <font color = red>nonholonomic</font> frame deformations (formally considered for nonholonomic manifolds and Finsler spaces) when the gravitational field equations transform into systems of nonlinear partial differential equations which can be integrated in general form. The new classes of solutions are defined by generic off-diagonal metrics depending on integration functions on one, two and three (or three and four) variables if we consider four (or five) dimensional <font color = red>spacetimes</font>. Second, we <font color = red>use</font> a general scheme when one (two) parameter families of exact solutions are defined by any source-free solutions of <font color = red>Einstein's</font> equations with one (two) Killing vector <font color = red>field</font>(s). A successive iteration procedure results in new classes of solutions characterized by an infinite number of parameters for a <font color = red>non-Abelian</font> group involving arbitrary functions on one variable. <font color = red>Five</font> classes of exact off-diagonal solutions are constructed in vacuum <font color = red>Einstein</font> and in string gravity describing solitonic <font color = red>pp-wave</font> interactions. We explore possible physical consequences of such solutions derived from primary Schwarzschild or pp-wave metrics.

original_text: The optimization of the pressure angle in a cam-follower transmission is reported in this paper. This transmission is based on <font color = red>Slide-o-Cam</font>, a cam mechanism with multiple rollers <font color = red>mounted</font> on a common translating follower. The design of Slide-o-Cam, a transmission intended to produce a <font color = red>sliding</font> motion from a turning <font color = red>drive</font>, or vice versa, was reported elsewhere. This transmission provides pure-rolling motion, thereby reducing the friction of rack-and-pinions and linear drives. The pressure angle is a suitable performance index for this transmission because it determines the amount of force transmitted to the <font color = red>load</font> vs. that transmitted to the machine frame. Two alternative design strategies are studied, namely, (i) increase the number of lobes on each <font color = red>cam</font> or (<font color = red>ii</font>) increase the number of <font color = red>cams</font>. This device is intended to replace the current ball-screws in Orthoglide, a three-DOF parallel robot for the production of <font color = red>translational</font> motions, currently under development at Ecole <font color = red>Centrale</font> de <font color = red>Nantes</font> for machining applications.

original_text: <font color = red>Spitzer</font> observations of extended dust in two optically normal elliptical galaxies provide a new confirmation of buoyant feedback <font color = red>outflow</font> in the hot gas atmospheres around these galaxies. <font color = red>AGN</font> feedback energy is required to prevent wholesale cooling and star formation in these group-centered galaxies. In NGC 5044 we observe <font color = red>interstellar</font> (<font color = red>presumably</font> <font color = red>PAH</font>) emission at 8 <font color = red>microns</font> out to about 5 kpc. Both NGC <font color = red>5044</font> and 4636 have extended <font color = red>70</font> microns emission from cold dust exceeding that expected from stellar mass loss. The sputtering lifetime of this extended dust in the ~1keV interstellar <font color = red>gas</font>, ~<font color = red>10</font>^7 yrs, establishes the time when the dust first entered the <font color = red>hot</font> gas. Evidently the extended dust originated in dusty disks or clouds, commonly observed in elliptical galaxy cores, that were disrupted, heated and buoyantly transported outward. The surviving <font color = red>central</font> dust in NGC <font color = red>5044</font> and <font color = red>4636</font> has been <font color = red>disrupted</font> into many small filaments. It is remarkable that the asymmetrically extended 8 micron emission in NGC 5044 is spatially coincident with Halpha+[<font color = red>NII</font>] emission from warm gas. A calculation shows that dust-assisted cooling in buoyant hot gas moving out from the galactic core can cool within a few <font color = red>kpc</font> in about ~10^7 <font color = red>yrs</font>, explaining the <font color = red>optical</font> line emission observed. The X-ray images of both galaxies are disturbed. All timescales for transient activity - restoration of equilibrium and buoyant transport in the hot gas, dynamics of surviving <font color = red>dust</font> fragments, and <font color = red>dust</font> sputtering - are consistent with a central release of feedback energy in both galaxies about <font color = red>10</font>^7 yrs <font color = red>ago</font>.

original_text: We present ACS/<font color = red>HST</font> coronagraphic observations of HD <font color = red>100546</font>, a <font color = red>B9</font>.5 star, <font color = red>103</font> <font color = red>pc</font> away from the sun, taken in the F435W, F606W, and F814W bands. Scattered light is detected up to <font color = red>14''</font> from the star. The observations are consistent with the presence of an extended flattened nebula with the same inclination as the inner disk. The <font color = red>well-known</font> ``spiral arms'' are clearly observed and they trail the rotating disk material. Weaker <font color = red>arms</font> never before reported are also seen. The inter-arm space becomes brighter, but the structures become more neutral in color at longer wavelengths, which is not consistent with models that assume that they are due to the effects of a warped disk. Along the major disk axis, the colors of the scattered-light relative to the star are \Delta (F435W-F606W) ~ 0.0--0.2 mags and \Delta (F435W-F814W)~0.5--1 mags. To explain these colors, we explore the role of asymmetric scattering, reddening, and large minimum sizes on ISM-like grains. We conclude each of these hypotheses by itself cannot explain the colors. original_text: In this work, we present a novel approach to the computation of Faithful Effective-One-Body (EOB) waveforms of small-mass-ratio coalescing black-hole binaries. The key idea is to use the fact that the gravitational-wave (GW) signal from such binaries is dominated by the dominant modes of the GW emission, and to compute the EOB waveform by a combination of analytical and numerical methods that allows to accurately track these modes.   Our methodology is based on a combination of analytic calculations of the dominant modes of the GW signal and numerical solutions of the EOB equations of motion with a high accuracy. We validate our approach by comparing our EOB waveforms with accurate numerical simulations of binary black-hole mergers, and find excellent agreement.   Our results show that the Faithful EOB waveforms we obtain are accurate enough to be used for data analysis of GW signals from small-mass-ratio binaries with current and future GW detectors, such as LIGO, Virgo, and the planned LISA mission. Moreover, our approach allows for a faster computation of EOB waveforms than current techniques, thus <font color = green>enabling</font> the analysis of a larger number of waveforms and the extraction of more information about the astrophysical properties of black-hole binaries.  <font color = green>The</font> motivation for this <font color = green>research</font> is to <font color = green>provide</font> accurate and computationally <font color = green>efficient</font> methods for the analysis of GW signals from small-mass-ratio binary black-hole mergers, which are expected to be detected with increasing <font color = green>sensitivity</font> in the near <font color = green>future</font>. <font color = green>Our</font> <font color = green>approach</font> may <font color = green>lead</font> to <font color = green>new</font> <font color = green>discoveries</font> about the <font color = green>nature</font> and <font color = green>properties</font> of black holes and their astrophysical environments.

original_text: We present our work on pairing based cooling of Fermi gases. The motivation for this research arises from the need to achieve lower temperatures and higher density in ultracold atomic gases. This field aims to study the behavior of gases at temperatures close to absolute zero, where classical physics can no longer accurately explain their behaviors. Studies have shown that Fermi gases can be cooled below their Fermi temperature by pairing fermions into composite bosons.   The key idea behind our work is to make use of this pairing mechanism to cool the Fermi gas even further. We propose to control the interaction between the fermions and the composite bosons by tuning external magnetic fields. Our methodology involves using numerical simulations to study the thermalization time scale of the Bose-Fermi mixture, as well as the overall cooling efficiency.   The problem we attempt to solve is the lack of efficient cooling methods for Fermi gases. Our <font color = green>pairing-based</font> cooling scheme <font color = green>offers</font> a <font color = green>new</font> avenue to achieve this goal. By using composite bosons to reduce the number of fermions, we can increase the density of the gas for a given temperature. Our results show that this method is effective in cooling a Fermi gas to lower temperatures than traditional cooling methods. We believe that our <font color = green>work</font> has the <font color = green>potential</font> to <font color = green>contribute</font> to the <font color = green>development</font> of more efficient cooling methods for ultracold atomic gases.

original_text: In this study, we explore constraints on the abundance of highly ionized proto-cluster regions by examining the absence of large voids in the Lyman Alpha forest. Proto-cluster regions, or regions of high-density gas that are the precursors of galaxy clusters, have been proposed as potential sources of ionizing radiation that can reionize the intergalactic medium. However, their abundance and contribution to reionization remain uncertain.   Using a large sample of high-resolution Lyman Alpha forest spectra from the Keck telescopes, we measure the sizes of voids in the forest and compare them with theoretical predictions based on different assumptions for the properties of proto-clusters. Our results indicate that the abundance of highly ionized proto-cluster regions cannot be too large, and must be consistent with current estimates from simulations and observations. We also find that the sizes of voids in the forest are sensitive to the density contrast of proto-clusters, suggesting that future observations of void sizes can provide valuable constraints on the properties of these elusive objects.  Our methodology involves a careful analysis of the Lyman Alpha forest data, including the identification and measurement of voids using state-of-the-art algorithms. We also use Monte Carlo simulations to test the statistical significance of our results and the robustness of our conclusions. Overall, our study provides a new and valuable perspective on the role of proto-cluster regions in reionizing the Universe, and highlights the importance of combining observational and theoretical approaches to address fundamental questions in cosmology.

original_text: In this study, we investigated the origin of the dichotomy of early-type galaxies, particularly the role of dry mergers and AGN feedback in shaping their stellar populations and morphologies. Our findings reveal that galaxies that have undergone dry mergers and those that have been affected by AGN feedback occupy different regions in the color-magnitude diagram, indicating distinct evolutionary paths. Dry merging results in redder and more massive galaxies with older stellar populations, while AGN feedback leads to bluer and lower mass systems with younger stars.  We also find that AGN activity plays a significant role in the formation of the innermost regions of early-type galaxies, particularly the presence of the central black hole and its interactions with the surrounding gas. Moreover, we detect a correlation between the mass of the central black hole and the velocity dispersion of the host galaxy, suggesting a possible coevolutionary process.  The motivation for this work <font color = green>stems</font> from the <font color = green>need</font> to understand the diversity of early-type galaxies and to unveil the physical mechanisms responsible for their observed properties. <font color = green>Our</font> results <font color = green>contribute</font> to the ongoing efforts to establish a <font color = green>comprehensive</font> <font color = green>picture</font> of galaxy evolution, <font color = green>shedding</font> <font color = green>light</font> on the intricate <font color = green>interplay</font> between galaxy mergers, AGN activity, and star formation in the early <font color = green>universe</font>.

original_text: In this work, we report the discovery of high-velocity outflows in massive post-starburst galaxies at a redshift of 0.6. These outflows reach speeds of up to 1000 km/s and are thought to be driven by intense star formation and the growth of central black holes.   These outflows are important as they can have a significant impact on the evolution of galaxies by regulating the amount of gas available for star formation and enriching the intergalactic medium with heavy elements. However, the detection of such outflows and their contribution to galactic evolution is challenging due to their short-lived nature and complex kinematics.  Using observations from the Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) at the Very Large Telescope, we study a sample of post-starburst galaxies and identify high-velocity outflows in approximately half of our sample. We analyze the kinematics and energetics of these outflows and find that they are consistent with being driven by intense star formation activity.  <font color = green>Our</font> findings have <font color = green>important</font> <font color = green>implications</font> for our <font color = green>understanding</font> of <font color = green>galaxy</font> evolution, as they <font color = green>suggest</font> that these outflows may be a common feature of post-starburst galaxies at high redshifts and may play a <font color = green>significant</font> <font color = green>role</font> in regulating the growth and activity of massive galaxies.

original_text: We present a novel approach to the problem of finding exact solutions to the equations of motion in gravity. Our method introduces a family of parameterized nonholonomic frame transforms, which enable a systematic and efficient exploration of the space of possible solutions. We demonstrate the power of our approach by considering several examples, including static spherically symmetric configurations, geodesic motion around a black hole, and gravitational waves. In all cases, we are able to derive exact solutions that are not only new, but also physically interesting and <font color = green>relevant</font> to <font color = green>current</font> astrophysical <font color = green>observations</font>. <font color = green>Moreover</font>, we show that our framework provides a <font color = green>natural</font> language to <font color = green>describe</font> non-trivial transformation properties of the <font color = green>solutions</font>, which can <font color = green>shed</font> <font color = green>light</font> on the <font color = green>nature</font> and symmetries of the <font color = green>underlying</font> <font color = green>physical</font> system. Our motivation for this <font color = green>research</font> <font color = green>stems</font> from the desire to <font color = green>understand</font> the <font color = green>fundamental</font> <font color = green>principles</font> <font color = green>underlying</font> <font color = green>gravity</font> and to <font color = green>find</font> new <font color = green>ways</font> to test Einstein's theory in the most extreme regimes. original_text: In this paper, we present a study on the design of a Slide-o-Cam Transmission, which aims to provide a solution to the problem of limited torque control in traditional transmissions. Our key idea in this work is to combine the benefits of a variable mechanical advantage system with a cam mechanism to create a transmission capable of achieving a significant range of gear ratios in a compact and efficient package.  The methodology employed in this study involved a combination of theoretical analysis, experimental testing, and computer simulations. We first derived the equations of motion for the sliding components of the transmission and used them to generate force and displacement profiles for different operating conditions. We then built a prototype transmission and tested it under various loads and speeds to validate the theoretical predictions and <font color = green>identify</font> areas for improvement. Finally, we developed a simulation model of the transmission using Matlab/Simulink to allow for more detailed <font color = green>analysis</font> of the system performance.  Our results demonstrate the effectiveness of the Slide-o-Cam Transmission in achieving high torque control in a compact, lightweight package. The transmission was found to have a wide range of gear ratios, high efficiency, and excellent load-carrying <font color = green>capacity</font>, <font color = green>making</font> it <font color = green>suitable</font> for <font color = green>use</font> in a <font color = green>variety</font> of applications. <font color = green>The</font> <font color = green>study</font> also provides insights into the design considerations for implementing such a transmission, <font color = green>including</font> the need for <font color = green>careful</font> <font color = green>selection</font> of materials and optimization of the cam profile. <font color = green>Overall</font>, our <font color = green>work</font> <font color = green>contributes</font> to the <font color = green>body</font> of <font color = green>knowledge</font> in the <font color = green>area</font> of <font color = green>mechanical</font> <font color = green>engineering</font> and has <font color = green>practical</font> <font color = green>applications</font> in the <font color = green>development</font> of <font color = green>innovative</font> transmission systems.

original_text: In this study, we present new evidence of recent feedback energy release in the cores of two elliptical galaxies based on Spitzer observations of the transient, extended dust. The key ideas behind our research are to investigate the mechanisms powering the high-energy processes in the nuclei of early-type galaxies and to understand their impact on the interstellar medium (ISM). The methodology employed in this work involves the analysis of imaging and spectroscopic data obtained with the Infrared Spectrograph (IRS) instrument on board the Spitzer Space Telescope. We detect extended dust features in the nuclei of NGC 5419 and IC 4296 that are spatially associated with outflows of hot gas and X-ray emission, indicative of an active galactic nucleus (AGN). Furthermore, we find that these dust structures have properties consistent with the presence of newly formed dust grains that have been heated by the AGN. The motivation for this study is to better understand the interplay between the AGN and the ISM in early-type galaxies, as this relationship has <font color = green>significant</font> <font color = green>implications</font> for galaxy evolution and the growth of supermassive black holes. <font color = green>Overall</font>, our <font color = green>work</font> <font color = green>represents</font> a <font color = green>step</font> <font color = green>forward</font> in our <font color = green>understanding</font> of feedback processes in <font color = green>galaxy</font> cores, and sheds <font color = green>light</font> on the physical conditions under which dust can be created and destroyed in these <font color = green>environments</font>.

We detect extended dust features in the nuclei of NGC 5419 and IC 4296 that are spatially associated with outflows of hot gas and X-ray emission, indicative of an active galactic nucleus (AGN). Furthermore, we find that these dust structures have properties consistent with the presence of newly formed dust grains that have been heated by the AGN. The motivation for this study is to better understand the interplay between the AGN and the ISM in early-type galaxies, as this relationship has <font color = red>signikicant</font> <font color = red>implicatbions</font> for galaxy evolution and the growth of supermassive black holes. <font color = red>Overal</font>, our <font color = red>worGk</font> <font color = red>represetns</font> a <font color = red>tep</font> <font color = red>froward</font> in our <font color = red>understanOing</font> of feedback processes in <font color = red>aglaxy</font> cores, and sheds <font color = red>lisght</font> on the physical conditions under which dust can be created and destroyed in these <font color = red>environmnts</font>.

original_text: In this study, we present the results of Hubble Space Telescope/Advanced Camera for Surveys (HST/ACS) coronagraphic observations of the dust surrounding HD 100546. The focus of our work is on the structure and morphology of the circumstellar dust disk and its interaction with a putative giant planet. The disk around HD 100546, which is known to contain evidence of both grain growth and dynamical interaction, presents a unique laboratory for investigating planet-disk interactions at an unusually advanced stage. Our observations reveal a relatively bright inner ring region that corresponds in location with a sharp rise in the spectral energy distribution. We found evidence for a gap beyond the ring, presumably carved by a massive protoplanet, and scattered light from dust particles presumably being displaced by the putative planet. The detailed structure of the disk is consistent with the presence of a relatively massive giant planet which injects sufficient energy to open a gap in the disk and simultaneously triggers the growth of a large inner ring via the Rossby vortices mechanism. Our findings <font color = green>suggest</font> that HD 100546 <font color = green>represents</font> a <font color = green>benchmark</font> <font color = green>system</font> to <font color = green>understand</font> the formation and evolution of young Jupiter-like planets.

original_text: In this study, we report the first CO J=6-5 and 4-3 detections in nearby ultra-luminous infrared galaxies (ULIRGs), with a focus on the dense gas in Mrk231. Using the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA), we traced these molecular transitions in the central region of Mrk231, where we found evidence of an extremely dense, compact molecular gas structure. Our proposed models suggest that the observed CO emission arises from high-density gas associated with the central engine rather than a rotating disk, as typically seen in lower-luminosity systems.  Our work aims to <font color = green>shed</font> <font color = green>light</font> on the gas kinematics in ultra-luminous star-forming galaxies, which are key systems in the formation and evolution of galaxies through cosmic time. Our results suggest that the dense gas reservoir in Mrk231 is limited, and that the cooling rate is not sufficient to meet the observed high star-formation rate. Therefore, the cooling budget may be supplemented by other mechanisms, such as feedback from the active galactic nucleus. A key outcome of our <font color = green>study</font> is that strong nuclear heating may be required in some ultra-luminous galaxies to offset the high cooling rate of their dense gas reservoirs and explain their ultraluminous infrared properties. Our findings have <font color = green>important</font> <font color = green>implications</font> for our <font color = green>understanding</font> of the <font color = green>interplay</font> between star formation and black hole activity in <font color = green>galaxy</font> <font color = green>evolution</font>.
